title: Getting divorced cost this woman nearly $1 million in retirement savings — how to avoid her fate when dissolving a marriage
text:
For Michelle Buonincontri, getting divorced wasn’t just an emotional blow, it was a significant financial setback.

Buonincontri, a certified financial planner and divorce financial analyst, estimates that her lack of a pre-nuptial agreement and the terms of her divorce settlement ultimately led to her losing out on about $1 million in retirement savings.

When Buonincontri got married in the 1990s, she and her then-husband each already owned property. They chose to live in the house that Buonincontri bought on her own with a roughly $20,000 down payment. The house was located in New York, and she had assumed that state law would protect her right to the home in the event of a divorce, because it was her own property.

“I should have had a marital agreement that said it was my property,” she said.

Eventually, Buonincontri’s own parents got divorced, and her father developed health issues. To support her father, Buonincontri and her husband agreed to refinance the home’s mortgage and give him the proceeds.

At the time though, Buonincontri was primarily a stay-at-home mother and was only working part-time as a financial planner while she went back to school to study for her financial planning certification. In order to qualify for the refinance, she added her husband to the house’s deed so that his income could count in the underwriting of the new loan.

Years later, when the couple initiated divorce proceedings, that decision came back to haunt her.

Divorce proceedings put a major strain on her retirement savings

Initially, the couple planned to go to a mediator to handle their divorce, which wouldn’t have been expensive. But they bowed to pressure from family and friends and took the court route instead.

Buonincontri and her ex-husband agreed to sell the home as part of the divorce settlement, with the proceeds meant to be split evenly between the two, even though she had originally purchased the home on her own.

Complicating matters, health concerns arose for one of Buonincontri’s two kids as the divorce was being finalized. In order to be closer to family for support, she decided to move to Arizona, where she now lives, over a very short period of time. She ultimately agreed to give up custody of her other child to her ex-husband so that she could leave New York.

Michelle Buonincontri and her ex-husband spent roughly $200,000 in legal fees to get divorced.

Her ex-husband did not want to sell the home, and because she was now living in another state it was more difficult for Buonincontri to follow up on the sale. Issues also came up regarding an individual retirement account Buonincontri retained in the divorce, which had contained both separate and marital assets. The divorce settlement did not reflect that she had kept this IRA as a concession in exchange for not receiving spousal support payments from her ex-husband and delaying child support. It also incorrectly identified the account as containing only Buonincontri’s own assets.

By this point, Buonincontri and her husband had spent around $200,000 in legal fees between the two of them, she said, which exhausted most her cash savings. On top of that, Buonincontri had to dip into her retirement savings and rack up credit card debt to secure housing in Arizona, furnish her new home and pay for her child’s expenses.

Faced with the prospect of going to court to try to compel the sale of the New York house and settle the dispute regarding the IRA, Buonincontri allowed her ex-husband to keep the home and not proceed with selling it. At the time, the equity in the home that would have been split after the mortgage was paid off would have added up to roughly $250,000.

“It’s had a significant impact on my retirement planning,” she said. “When I moved I had to dip into my retirement assets to buy a home for me and my children because I didn’t have that money.”

Between the lost return on the sale of the home and the costs she incurred to pay for a lawyer and move across the country, Buonincontri lost around $200,000 that would have gone toward her retirement. Given that the stock market’s average return is around 10% annually, those funds would have grown to $1 million over 20 years. Those calculations don’t include the additional savings she missed out on as she worked to pay off the debt she accrued in this time.

She has not yet earned that money back. “I’m still working towards that,” she said. “It was a huge loss. Based on the trajectory my husband and I had at the time, we could have retired at 50 with several million dollars.”

‘Just like you plan for death by having life insurance, you should think about your marriage the same way — what if divorce happens?’ —Michelle Buonincontri, a certified financial planner at Being Mindful in Divorce

What she could have done differently — before she got married

As Buonincontri says, no one gets married thinking they’re going to get divorced. But it’s important to be realistic and honest about finances when choosing to get married.

“Folks are more likely to talk about their sex life or their most recent encounter on Tinder MTCH, -1.63% than they are to talk about finances,” she said.

Because both she and her ex-husband had significant assets before they got married, the two could have avoided a lot of frustration down the road had they drafted a pre-nuptial agreement. “Just like you plan for death by having life insurance, you should think about your marriage the same way — what if divorce happens?” she said.

Additionally, it’s important to work together as a couple to determine which assets to keep separate and which are considered jointly owned.

Courtesy of Michelle Buonincontri Inspired by her own experience with divorce, Michelle Buonincontri now works as a certified divorce financial analyst, helping other couples to work out equitable divorce settlements.

The benefits of having a financial analyst in divorce proceedings

Around two years after she moved to Arizona, Buonincontri got her divorce financial analyst certification, and today she advises clients who are ending marriages through her firm, Being Mindful in Divorce. “I wanted other families to know there are alternatives,” she said. “Had a CDFA been part of my process, it would have made things clearer.”

Buonincontri said she turns to her personal experience with divorce when working with clients. Certified divorce financial analysts are hired to help couples looking to end a marriage work through the division of their assets to ensure an equitable settlement. CDFAs can be hired to work on behalf of one or both spouses.

When they work with both spouses, the CDFA plays a neutral role. They typically ask to see multiple years’ worth of financial statements, including bank statements, credit card bills, tax returns and retirement statements. They use these documents to verify the information on the affidavit of financial information provided to the court.

“It just becomes about the data. It helps to take the emotions out of the economics.” —Buonincontri, on the benefits of working with a divorce financial analyst

Beyond just looking at assets, these financial analysts will also study the couple’s cash flow and model expected future returns on investments to ensure that the ultimate settlement is fair for both parties. A CDFA can also help a person seeking a divorce to get a budget in place as they adjust to life being single once again.

One of the biggest benefits Buonincontri sees in hiring a CDFA is to help approach the divorce negotiations more rationally. It can also help people set better priorities.

“You get bullied and overwhelmed with the process as it drags out,” she said. “When you work with a CDFA, it just becomes about the data. It helps to take the emotions out of the economics.”
description: As a financial analyst, Michelle Buonincontri now works to help people achieve equitable divorce settlements.
